text: [Music]
hello everyone my name is Vijay potala
I'm a Senior Product Manager at Amazon
Web Services my focus area is lambda H
lambda Raj is a global service computing
service that allows you to run functions
that are 150 plus edge locations around
the world this enables developers to
build highly customized web and mobile
applications and api's at low latencies
for the end users today I'll walk you
through setting up a simple example of
lambda rich function on your Amazon
CloudFront distribution you can follow
similar steps to build many advanced
customizations possible using lambda Raj
let's quickly look at our website if you
scroll down to the use cases section
these examples give you a good sense of
what you can build using lambda Raj for
example you can customize your user
experience like a be testing managing
user authorization for your payable
content you can also use lambda H to
simplify your origin infrastructure by
offloading a portion of that logic
globally to the edge for example you can
move your security and privacy header
logic for all your properties to the
edge you can do real-time image
transformations global routing and load
balancing automatic bought medications
and more in this tutorial we will learn
how to add security and privacy headers
to HTTP responses that CloudFront
receives from your origin before we get
started if you haven't already done so
sign up for AWS choose create an a SS
account and enter the required
information to complete signup also this
tutorial assumes that you have a Crofton
environment to work with and that
includes knowledge in to serve content
from but if you don't have that set up
already please take few minutes to set
up your CloudFront distribution before
you proceed with this tutorial please
take a look at our getting started page
on cloud and website if you scroll down
here you can see simple quick video
tutorial for setting up Clapham
distribution and with s3 origin alright
let's get started
this tutorial is broken down into four
steps we will first create a lambda
function with a logic to add security
headers to the HTTP responses next we
will perform a unit test for the
function using sample test events
provided by the lambda console then we
will configure the CloudFront trigger
for the created function and finally we
will verify whether your function runs
on your CloudFront distribution as
expected let's start with creating a
lambda function sign into the a lab list
management console open the a SS lamda
console make sure you are in US East one
Northern Virginia region you must be in
this region to create lambda race
functions now choose create function on
the create function page you can choose
one of the following options to create
your function I will be using a
blueprint for this tutorial as the name
suggests blueprints give you a good
starting point with sample code and
configuration presets for common use
cases choose blueprints and then filter
for the Crofton blueprints type Crofton
in the search field and then press
return the keyword crowdfund is shown
and all the blueprints are attacked for
CloudFront are listed from the results
choose the CloudFront modify response
header blueprint to use as a template
for this function this template gives
you a good starting point for modifying
the code to add security headers to
responses from the origin now enter the
information about your function function
name choose execution roll for your
function it's easiest to get started by
using the basic lambda raj permissions
so for this option choose create new
roll from policy templates you can see
that basic H damn'd of permissions is
automatically added for you because you
chose a cloud from blueprint as a basis
for your function adding age lambda
permissions to the execution roll allows
CloudFront to run your lambda functions
for you in addition to pushing execution
logs to cloud watch enter the roll name
if you scroll down you can see the
sample code provided by the blueprint we
selected go to the bottom of the page
click create function within few seconds
lambda creates your function we can now
go ahead and change the code and
configuration as needed before that
let's quickly look at how the function
configuration page is structured
let's start with the designer
on the left you can see different evil
sources that can be configured to
trigger lambda function we also see a
visual representation of your function
configuration since we selected cloud
phone blueprint the cloud front trigger
is automatically added with pending
deployment information we'll get to that
later choose the function box to
highlight it as you scroll down you can
see the cloud nine IDE where you can
edit the code further down the page
there are some additional configuration
settings that you can modify for example
you can increase the memory or for your
function based on your performance needs
for this tutorial we will leave it at
default values also note that some of
the settings like Network dlq are not
applicable for lambda reg going back to
the function code I replace the header
section of the code with the logic to
our security headers in the function we
are simply adding these headers to the
response from the origin before
returning the response to the end users
now click Save let's quickly unit test
the function by using the sample test
events provided by the console the
function can have up to 10 test events
the events are persisted so you can
switch to another computer or web
browser and test your function with the
same events
now select configure test event as you
can see the sample even template is
automatically added based on the coffin
blueprint we chose even template is just
a JSON object to be consumed by the
lambda in this test event JSON object
emulates a sample 200 response generated
by the origin including some headers
that are added at the origin itself
enter even name and click create now
going back to the main configuration
page all the test events that you create
will show up here
Silvia test even that we just created
and click test console provides you the
execution result succeeded or failed
along with details in this case as you
can see the function execution succeeded
click here to expand details as you
scroll through the result it end by a
function execution we can see security
headers got added to the JSON object
the summary of execution also includes
some metadata for the function execution
for example duration resource configured
and memory used close this tab and go
back to configuration page the next step
is to configure a cloud from trigger to
run your function choose the CloudFront
box to highlight it below in the
configure trigger section choose deploy
to lambda reg to open the page where you
can define the trigger and then deploy
it select the cloud from distribution ID
to associate with a function in the
drop-down list choose a distribution ID
select the cache behavior to use with
the trigger for this tutorial leave the
value set to star which applies your
distributions default cache behavior to
all requests choose the cloud for an
event this trigger specifies when your
function will run we warned the security
headers function to run whenever Crofton
receives a response from the origin so
in the drop-down list choose origin
response event under confirm deploy to
lambda h select the checkbox to
acknowledge that a new function version
will be created and the trigger will be
deployed in order to aid of research
locations finally choose deploy the
deployment usually takes a few minutes
but can take up to eight minutes you can
check to see if replication is finished
by going to the conference console and
viewing a distribution status click here
check for the distribution status to
change from in progress back to deployed
which means that your function has been
replicated now that we have deployed the
function to our aida base locations
around the world let's verify that the
function works by accessing the cloud
from distribution in a browser type the
URL for your distribution that you
configure to trigger lambda function for
example you might use a URL similar to
this open your browser's web developer
toolbar for example in your browser's
window in Firefox open the context menu
and then choose Network reload the page
to view your image again on the right
side you can see various parameters of
the request and response under header
section look through the list of headers
to verify that the expected security
headers are included in the list for
example you might see header similar to
those in the fall
screenshot if the security headers are
included in your headers list great you
have successfully created your first
lambda rich function this concludes the
tutorial for setting up lambda rich
function Phi a CloudFront distribution
be sure to look at the additional
resources on this page with links to
lambda rich blog post and design best
practices
[Music]
[Applause]
